verses.text: Wisdom has built her house; she has hewn out its seven pillars.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9
rsbNotes.text: 9:1–18 This section consists of two competing invitations, one from wisdom and the other from folly. Both are portrayed as women calling people to enter their houses. Wisdom invites the simple to eat of her life-giving food (vv. 1–12). Folly offers food that leads to death (vv. 13–18).

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:1
rsbNotes.text: 9:1 her seven pillars. The significance of “seven pillars” is not clear. It may simply indicate the architectural splendor of the house. However, “seven” often symbolizes perfection or completeness, and so may here represent the perfection of divine wisdom.

verses.text: She has prepared her meat and mixed her wine; she has also set her table.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:2
rsbNotes.text: 9:2 mixed her wine. The mixture was probably of wine and spices (Song 8:2).

verses.text: She has sent out her maids, and she calls from the highest point of the city.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:3
rsbNotes.text:
9:3 her young women. Wisdom’s servants are sent out to summon any who will hear her invitation to life.

from the highest places. The invitation is open and universal (Is. 52:7).

verses.text: "Let all who are simple come in here!" she says to those who lack judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:4
rsbNotes.text:
9:4 simple. See 1:4 and note. Note the competing call of folly in v. 16.

lacks sense. Lit. “lacks heart,” the will to think and act rightly.

verses.text: "Come, eat my food and drink the wine I have mixed.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:5
rsbNotes.text: 9:5 Come, eat. A banquet is the right setting for the food distributed by wisdom. The banquet motif is later used to portray the blessings of the redeemed (Is. 55:1, 2; Matt. 22:1–13; 26:29; Rev. 19).

verses.text: Leave your simple ways and you will live; walk in the way of understanding.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:6
rsbNotes.text: 9:6 Leave your simple ways, and live. See 1:4, 22; 2:19; 3:2, 18; 8:35 and notes.
